question.title: Environment Minister
question.notes: 'Torrential rain drowns UK' was the recent headline in The National Post. Flooding has damaged property and stranded people in their homes.

questions.text: How much does the Minister estimate it will cost to clean up and repair people's homes after the recent flooding?
questions.feedback: Good question! It helped you find out how well prepared the Government is for flooding emergencies.

questions.text: Does the Minister agree that the weather has been quite bad lately?
questions.feedback: MPs don't ask for the Minister's opinion on things during Question Time. Try reading your brief next time, then ask for some relevant information.

missed.feedback: Question Time is a good chance to check to see what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Business Minister
question.notes: A new survey shows that school leavers are worried about finding their first job when they finish their studies. The National Post reported 43% of the young people surveyed said they were 'stressed out about it'.

questions.text: What steps is the Government taking to reduce youth unemployment?
questions.feedback: Good topical question. Students in your constituency will appreciate it.

questions.text: Does the Minister know who invented the telephone?
questions.feedback: Question Time in the House of Commons isn't for requesting information that's easily available elsewhere. (Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone by the way).

missed.feedback: Question Time is a good opportunity to check the work of the Government and raise your own profile to show that you're working for your constituents.

question.title: Global Affairs Minister
question.notes: A huge earthquake in the Middle East has left thousands homeless. The UK Government is helping in the emergency relief effort to house at least 15,000 people.

questions.text: Will the Minister make a statement about the UK relief effort following the big earthquake in the Middle East?
questions.feedback: Good question. You got the Minister to explain what his department has been doing to help the homeless.

questions.text: The ground seems solid enough. Can the Minister explain why earthquakes happen?
questions.feedback: That's a question for science class. MPs must ask ministers questions that are relevant to their duties.

questions.text: What plans does the Government have for an early warning system for earthquakes in the UK?
questions.feedback: The Minister gave a short answer and the press ignored your question. Most people were interested in the big quake in the Middle East.

missed.feedback: Where were you? You missed a check up on how well the Global Affairs Minister has been doing his job.

question.title: Prime Minister
question.notes: MPs fill the House of Commons Chamber to be part of Prime Minister's Questions. This is when MPs have the chance to ask the Prime Minister about anything the Government is doing.

questions.text: What plans does the Government have to help small businesses?
questions.feedback: That was a good question for your constituency. It has hundreds of small businesses.

questions.text: What is the Government doing to ensure the UK tourist industry has continued success?
questions.feedback: Your constituency has a big theme park - its owner and employees were glad you're supporting their industry.

questions.text: Does the Prime Minister know what the capital of Pakistan is?
questions.feedback: Your questioning style was treated harshly by the papers: 'Clueless MP embarrasses their party'.

missed.feedback: PMQs is a great chance to check the work of the Government (and raise your profile).

question.title: Culture Minister
question.notes: A small handful of young artists and musicians have started successful careers after getting financial help from their friends and families. Your constituency has a large artistic community.

questions.text: What steps are the Government taking to encourage private citizens to donate to the arts?
questions.feedback: Your question raised the profile of an issue important to your constituents

questions.text: Does the Minister agree with me that the Opposition party's view on arts funding is just plain crazy?
questions.feedback: The Speaker cut you off after that question. Question Time is meant for checking the work of the Government. You can't ask ministers for their opinion about the Opposition party.
'MP flouts question rules' was The National Post headline. That question wasn't relevant to the Minister's duties.

missed.feedback: You missed Question Time with the Culture Minister. Artists in your constituency might continue to struggle.
